monogr.title: An apolagy of the Holy Sea apostolicks proceeding for the gouernment of the Catholics of England during the tyme of persecution : VVith a defense of a religious state, vvritten by Daniel of Iesus reader of Diuinity
monogr.author: Floyd, John

div.head: THE PREFACE To the Reader.
div.p:
CHRISTIAN history recordes memorable exampl •• of famous men▪ who hauing written victoriously •
gainst heresy, towar • s the end of their dayes by a certaine 〈◊〉 all • cclipse darkened the glory of their former renowne, the causes of their declining hauing been their immoderat desire of Episcopall dignity from which they were held backe, or emulation against some persons singularly honoured by the soueraigne Pastour, or ouerbould censuring of the sea Apostolique for some proceeding by them disliked. As I may ranke M. Doctour amongst those worthies in regard of his morning euer honoured writings, so I will not goe to compare this his later labour with their euening workes, further then with a wish they were more vnlike, and that there were lesse of that smoake which doth not vse to fume frō heauēly fier.

2. In the drift of his writing he may seem to resemble the Sea-Crabb, which looketh on way and goeth another, or a riuer which seeming calme & stil aboue, inwardly runnes with mayne force. His treatise titularly pretendes to be written against the Anarchy of Caluine, and a Chapter or two be inserted in which that cōtrouersy is superficially hādled: that
which his whole discourse would really performe is to condemne that forme of gouerment for the Catholikes of Englād, which the holy sea thought most fit for vs during persecution, to wit, by doing 〈◊〉 the honour to make England the speciall charg •
• f their Episcopal care without any other part • cular B • shop, wherein those holy Princes & Pastour, haue shewed towards vs such fatherly prouidence by founding themselues, and inducing Catholike Princes to found Seminaries of clergy abroad, that in greatest straights a competent number of vertuous Priests was neuer heer wanting, & now, (as M. Doctour doth glory) we enioy a flourishing Cleargy, which we could neuer haue expected had the principall care of vs been leaft vnto a Domesticall Bishops

3. Notwithstanding in this treatise this course of gouerment is impugned as Anarchicall, as taking away the uery essence of a particular Church; as depriuing vs of that Sacrament without which Christians cannot be perfect in that very time when perfection is specially necessary; as being a continual violation of the deuine Law; as a going against the perpetuall practise of the ancient Church, which in the greater fury of persecution neuer omitted to giue their Bishops to euery particular Church. Heerwith he mingleth mighty cōmendaciōs of Episcopal dignitye & state to make the vulgar sort to be enāoured of a Bishop, and to be the readier to yeeld to his suggection to admit of my Lord of Chalcedon as their Bishop, their spirituall King and Prince of Pastours; wheras his Hollines will haue him receaued but as a delegate at the most, In the ordering likewise of the Ecclesiasticall Hierarchy though he pretend therin to proceed with great contradiction of Caluine; yet
would he faine displace those sacred Rankes, which Caluin did more feare and hate then some of those M. Doctours affection would prefere.

4. His treatise in the inward disposition thereof & very bowels tending to reprehēd the constant practise of the piller of truth, hardly may we expect his doctrine should be euery way sound; yet the censure thereof I leaue to others, the iudiciall to the chaire of Peeter, the iudicious to the learned reader to be giuen vpon exact discussion, which I haue endeauoured to make in this my Answere. Onely this I dare affirme, that strong affectio to the reuerend Order of Secular English Priests, ioyned with ardent desire to see Bishops amongst them, hath caused his pen to runne towards that side, (I will not say from Catholike like truth) but from Catholike current opinion, further than otherwise his learning deuoyd of partiality would haue gonne. The same zeale is the cause that euery where about these matters he vseth darke and ambiguous sentences, which the vulgar reader can hardly cōceiue, but in an erroneous sense, fauouring his cause, though perchance by some subtill distinction he may contend that was not his meaning.

5. This also I may say (and learned men that haue perused the treatise will concurre in opinion with) me that this treatise is not to compare with his former writings for exactnes; yea he giueth his hereticall aduersary (against whom he would seem to write) many aduantages to insult ouer, him, and Catholiks for his sakes. Such be some m • sprisiōs in scripture, as where he saith. c. 1. n. 13. Iob in his fourth chapter, speaketh of Behemoth the great fish, wheras Iob there describeth Behemoth as a great beast feeding
vpon the grasse of mountaines. And againe, in the same nūber the scripture compareth Lucifer to Behemoth adorned with mine preatious stones; where is Behemoth adorned with preatious stones found in scripture? He saith c. 9. n. 14. that at the first Bishops & Priests only preached the Ghospell, and conuerted countreys; is not this great forgetfulnes? Who doth not know that S. Stephen, neither Bishop nor Priest, but only Deacon preached the Ghospell, as also did Philip the Deacon, who by preaching conuerted Samaria? To preferre Bishops before Angels for office, he saith c. 7. n. 2. cut Angelorum dictum est paescite qui in vobis est gregem Dei? to which of the Angels was it euer said, feed the flocke of God that is amongst you as to Bishops it was sayed. To which questiō one might readily answeare out of the Woord of God, to those Angels of whom the Psalmist saith Psalm. 90. v. 12. Angelis suis manda • it de te in omnibus vijs tuis. He hath giuen chardge to his Angels ouer thee to keepe thee in all thy wayes. For Angels to haue charge to keep the sheep & flocke of God, what is it but to be their Pastour?

6. The like mistaking he hath about Ecclesiastical history, as c. 13 n. 11. where discribing the cruelty of the Arian Tyrant Trasimūdus, he citeth for authour Orosius l. 1. c. 10. where no such thing is found, and Orosius was dead many a faire yeare before that time. In the number of Popes that suffered from Nero to Constantine, he placeth Ioannes. Siluerius and Martinus who suffered more then two hundred yeares after; c. 13. n. 6 amongst the persecution of the Church he putteth the persecutiō of Vespatianus a thing neuer before named, or hardof. In the same place he commendeth the Roman Bishops namly Corn • llus that then in persecution they neuer
intermitted the Su • cession by long Sea-uacancy, where as before the election of Cornelius there was a Sea-u •• ancy of sixteen monthes, longer then any euer happened before, or after either within a thousand yeares.

7: He hath discourses that do rather eneruate then giue force vnto the Catholike arguments he boroweth of others As c. 3. n 14, hauing that proued S. Peter was made Pastour of the church of Christ by the words Pasce oues meas, he makes S. Peter speake to extoll his owne dignity ouer his fellow Apostles in this manner. If saith he) S. Peter after that he had receaued this charge ouer Christs sheep should haue demaunded of the rest of the Apostles are you the sheep of Christ they could not haue denied it▪ and then Peter m • ght haue subsinned; If you be the sheep of Christ you are m • sheep, because Christ without d • stinction c • mitted al his • heep to me. And if you be my sheep, I am your Pastour & Superiour, because 〈◊〉 Sheep is a name of subiection; so Pastour is a name of superioritye. And if I be your Pastour, who are all soe Pastoures, I am Pastor Pastorum, the Pastour of Pastours, and for the Pastour of you and your shepe, and consequently of all the Church. Seing M. Doctour was pleased to play the Rhetorician in this place and vse a pro • opopea, he might more discretely haue giuē the speech in prayse of S. Peter and his dignity to •• me other person than S. Peter himselfe, and haue followed that aduise of wisedome laudet te os aliruum & non os cuum be thou praysed by anothers mans mouth, and not by thine owne Yo • the making of S. Peter to dispute with his fellow Apostles about his primacy was more thē needlesse; us who should say they were doubtful thereof. And M. Doctours vrging the commō argumen would haue been mo •• s • ll • l • , had it been further
from the least insinuatiō of Apostolical backewardnes in this poynt to be disputed agaynst, as indeed there was none, they being after our sauiours Ordinance euer more ready to acknowledge thā S. Peter to exercise his supreme iurisdiction ouer them.

8. He maketh Doctrines to be of faith vpon groundes uery weake, as c. 8. n. 8. hee saith, it is certaine that Deacōs & Subdeacōs are of the deuine institution because the Councell of Trent doth denounce Anathema to any that shall say that the Hierarchy instituted by Diuine Ordinance doth not constare ex Episcopis et Presbiteris & Ministris, confest of Bishops, Priests and Ministers, by Ministers (saith he) in the plurall we must needs vnderstād at least Deacons & Subdeacons; who wil not presētly perceaue the weaknesse of this arguing? For the Councell also saith in the plurall Priests are of the Hierarchy, and yet this doth not import different kinds of Priests but only many Priests of the same kind. In like manner the Councels might say Ministers in the plural to signifye many Ministers of the same kind, to wit many of the order of deacons. How poore a proofe then is this that M. Doctour should hereō conclude, that it is certaiē that there be Ministers of different kindes; at the least Deacons & Subdeacons. These and the like examples of some ouersight and weakenes that may be brought, shew that M. Doctour in writing this treatise was not moued with so light some zeale and so deuoyd of smoake, as he did his former workes, that with much honour both to himselfe, & the Church this might haue been suppressed.

9. Howsoeuer; veneration due to his person will make me firmely perswaded, that whatsoeuer defect may be found in this writing; yet it is not
such, but we may compare him with one frō whom a temporall slipp • nto e •• or tooke not away the eternall stile of Saint, I mean S. Cyprian. I will presume that conceiued necessity of a Bishop without any ambition of that honour, sincere loue of presumed truth in the behalf • of the Secular Cleargy, no secret instinct of enuy against Regulars, moued his hād and hart in this writing, that wherin he may seem to mistake, is but a token of humane frailty, & no such fayling in Charity, but S. Augustines excuse for S, Cyprian may agree vnto him, naeuum in candidissimo pectore sanctae illius animae charitatis vbera contegebant (l. 1 de Baptismo cap. 19.) the mole that did somwhat blemish, the candide breast of that holy soule with the breasts of his charity was hidden.

10. Which charity (I confide) will moue him not to be offended at this Apology for the proceeding of the sea Apostolike, & for the perfection of Religious state, it being for the good of human kind, and for the saluation of soules most important, that these two pillars, the one of Truth, the other of Sanctity be not in the least manner violated, especiall by any of our English nation, we being behoulding aboue all to the one, and the other for our conuersion from Paganisme, yea to the first also at this present for our subsisting in persecution (for of the second how they concurre both at home and abroad to the furtherāce of this worke and aduancing of the Cleargy in learning & holy education I wil say nothing). If in this treatise I discouer his mistaking in citing authours to his purpose against their meaning, & sometimes not so fully and faythfully, he will not be soe much greeued at our laying open that defect, as at his owne ouerferuent vndertaking a cause that could
not be without such helpe (which truth neuer needeth) defended, and what Bellarmine said of S. Cyprian (l. 4. d • verb. Dei • . c. 11.) may without much discredit of his learning be true in h • m nurum non est • ypriav • m errantem errantum more rati ••• art: o • what himselfe saith p. 2 • 3. of the worthy Cardinal Turrecremata. He was a most learned man, though learned men be men & so may be ouer seen.

list.head: The points that be handled.
list.item: 1. That a particular Church may subsi •• wi hout a Bishop.
2. That Confirmatiō is not so necessary in time of persecutiō.
3 That the Diuine law doth not so inuiollably require a Bishop in euery Church.
4. That the Primitiue Church in such circumstances we are in would neuer haue placed Bishops in En • land.
5. Whether Regulars haue an eminēt place in the Hierarchy?
6. That the state of Bishops is not so absolutely & in all respects more perfect than the state of Religion.
8. Whether s • culars haue by diuine ordinance right and authority to preach to Gentils &c. Regulars only by Papall authority?
9. How M. Doctours vrging Catholikes to entertaine my Lord of Chalcedon as their Bishop and spirituall Prince is not reasonable.
